MAPPING RELATIVE OLIVINE CONTENT IN MARE BASALTS USING M3 DATA.  M. Staid1, J. Sunshine2 and S. Besse3, 1Planetary Science Institute, 1700 East Fort Lowell, Suite 106, Tucson, AZ 85719 (staid@psi.edu), 2Dept. of Astronomy, University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20742, 3ESA/ESAC, Science and Operation division, Villanueva de la Canada, Madrid, Spain.   Introduction:  The last phases of lunar volcanism produced large areas of high-titanium basalt on the western nearside of the Moon that have different reflectance properties than older, sampled lunar maria.  Studies of remote sensing data have predicted that these flows contain higher iron and olivine contents than earlier lunar basalts [1-5] and occur as recognizable sequences of volcanism characterized by increasing olivine content over time [2,5].  Recently, the Yutu rover on the Chinese Chang'E-3 mission confirmed the presence of abundant olivine in a subset of these basalts located in Mare Imbrium based on in-situ measurements of basaltic fragments using VIS-NIR and x-ray spectrometers [6,7].   Previous studies suggest that the youngest flows in Oceanus Procellarum are likely to contain some of the most olivine and iron rich basalts within these western maria [5].  In order to assess the relative olivine abundances of basalts throughout Imbrium and Procellarum, a simplified version of the Modified Gaussian Model (MGM) [8, 9] is being applied to provide an objective method of comparing relative olivine to pyroxene contents for mare units mapped using Moon Mineralogy Mapper (M3) imaging spectrometer data.  Previous Work:   The work presented here is part of a larger study of the mineralogy and stratigraphy of late-stage mare volcanism in Imbrium and Oceanus Procellarum that combines reflectance data acquired by M3 with measurements obtained by other lunar missions.  Recent efforts include mapping of 83 compositional units within Mare Imbrium [10, 11] as well as a smaller number of units in the Lichtenberg and Marius Hills regions of Oceanus Procellarum [12,13].   Within each mapped unit, the spectral properties of small optically immature mare craters have been sampled to characterize the mineralogy of emplaced basalts [e.g. 11].  By identifying 'fresh' craters that fall along the optical weathering trends of local soils and craters, this approach provides comparisons of basalt mineralogy that minimize the effects of space weathering and nonmare mixing.   Spectral properties associated with olivine in these basalts are primarily observed within the smallest craters sampling the uppermost 10s of meters of regional high-titanium flows.   This pattern of thin olivine-rich deposits has been observed in the uppermost stratigraphy of high titanium basalts in both Mare Imbrium and Oceanus Procellarum [11-13].  Some of the most extreme spectral differences between neighboring basalts occur east of Lichtenberg crater in a region thought to contain some of the youngest mare flows on the Moon [e.g. 14].  Spectra from this region have been selected for initial applications of the simplified MGM models presented here.  Figure 1:  M3 integrated band depth mosaic showing large-scale spectral units surrounding Lichtenberg crater (L). Stratigraphically younger high titanium flows containing olivine appear red due to weaker 2μm ferrous bands relative to absorptions at 1μm while feldspathic materials appear blue. Red=1μm IBD, green=2μm IBD, blue=1.58μm. Stratigraphic boundaries for the high-Ti basalts (in white) are from [12].   Data Analysis:  Initial MGM analyses of the relative olivine and pyroxene contents of mare basalts have focused on spectra derived from fresh mare craters located in the Lichtenberg study region (Figure 1).  Specifically, basalts from units A and C are predicted to have the highest olivine content of the mare flows mapped in this region but have different continuum slopes and inferred titanium contents [12].  These two basalts are compared here to lower titanium pyroxene rich basalts from unit E.   An analysis of all potential absorptions resulting from variations in the mineralogy of lunar basalts would be poorly contrained by the spectral resolution and range of the M3 data.  Instead, a simplified model based on the approach of [9] has been adopted here to a b c d e 50 kmL 2531.pdf

characterize the relative strength of major absorptions related to olivine and pyroxene within these basalts.  Two simplified four and six band MGM models were used to fit the olivine and pyroxene absorptions observed in the M3 data of fresh craters from each mare unit.  The relative contribution of olivine within the three mare regions was then assessed based on comparisons of the derived band strengths near 1.0, 1.3 and 2.0 μms.  The goal of this approach is to provide an objective method for the analysis of M3 data to compare the strength of absorptions resulting from variations in olvine and pyroxene content. Results:  Examples of the four band MGM fits to mare units A and E are shown in Figure 2.  Despite using only four bands to model variations in pyroxene and olivine within these basalts, a relatively good fit is obtained that provides a means for comparing the strength of the absorption at 1.3 μm (due to olivine) to the combined strength of the 1 μm (pyroxene and olivine) and 2 μm (pyroxene only) absorption bands.    MGM results for both the four and six band models are summarized in Figure 3 which shows the ratio of the 1.3 μm band strength to the combined strength of the 1 and 2 μm bands.  Both the four and six band MGM models predict high olivine to pyroxene ratios for the high titanium units A and C consistent with previous qualitative interpretations of these basalts [12].  Lower 1.3 μm band strength ratios are obtained for the older low-titanium basalts (unit E) consistent with a pyroxene dominated basalt mineralogy.  Future work will continue to test and refine these simplified MGM models for application to the broader range of mare compositions being mapped throughout Mare Imbrium and Oceanus Procellarum, providing comparisons of olivine content between spectrally mapped units and to the basalts recently measured by the Yutu rover.
